oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nashville City Schools, Ross School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Located on Grove Avenue, which later became Ordway Place, Ross School was erected in 1907. The school was named for Marcus M. Ross who worked as a teacher and principal for Nashville city schools. In 1933, a tornado that swept through East Nashville damaged the school building. The structure closed in 1988, and a new building was constructed on McFerrin Avenue at the site of the old East High School football field.11 x 14 in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ross School
Education; architecture; Schools
Nashville (Tenn.); Grove Avenue; ordway Place
